bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 168, Number 140 (Tuesday, August 30, 2022)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. NEAL:H.R. 8761.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8 of the United States Constitution.[Page H7731]

item.name: Crime, Terrorism, and Homeland Security Subcommittee

item.title: A bill to add Ireland to the E-3 nonimmigrant visa program.

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary. (text: CR S1255)

item.name: Crime, Terrorism, and Homeland Security Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, and Homeland Security.
Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

summary.text: This bill expands the E-3 visa program to cover Irish nationals. The E-3 visa is a nonimmigrant visa currently only available to Australian nationals coming to the United States for employment in a specialty occupation. For Irish E-3 initial applications, the Department of State may approve each fiscal year no more than 10,500 minus the number of Australian initial applications approved the previous fiscal year.

bill.title: To add Ireland to the E-3 nonimmigrant visa program.

item.title: To add Ireland to the E-3 nonimmigrant visa program.
To add Ireland to the E-3 nonimmigrant visa program.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, and Homeland Security.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
